cards.name: The user must be able to change the source of the data
The user requires a graphical interface to the system
The researcher wants to know the number of publications and the number of authors, both overall and broken down by publication type
The researcher wants to know the number of publications for each author, both overall and by publication type
The researcher want to know the number of publications produced in a year, broken down by publication type
The researcher wants to know the number of authors who wrote publications in each year, broken down by publication type
The user can find out how many articles have been produced by the School in total and break this down into year and publication type (journal, conference, book, book chapter). [2]
The user can find out the total number of authors and, for each author, give the number of publications they have produced of each type. [2]
The user can find out, for each author, the total number of co-authors and the average number of co-authors for each type of publication. [2]
The user can output data into CSV format from tables [2]
The user can view publication details [2]
The user can obtain a list of all co-authors for each author. [3]
The user can visualise the collaboration network. [5]
The user can split the collaborators between internal and external authors. [20]
The school can provide a web application that presents the information to external visitors. [10]
The user can access the application through mobile device [4]
Box and whisker plot for the number of co-authors for each author [5]
The user can explore an expandable network centered around the author. [15]
The user can view connections on a zoomable map. [20]
The user should be able to read all data from dblp and update as it changes [20]
The user can see connections between authors in an adjacency matrix [5]
The user can filter the data through a series of interactive charts. [15]
The user can see a word cloud showing all co-authors. [5]
The user can split the collaborators by their discipline. [20]
The user must log in to access the data [10]
Simple Prototype

Andreas Demetriou

@andreasdemetriou I've noticed that Robert appears twice in the dataset that will be used for assessment (separately with and without his middle initial).  Not sure we can do anything about that but should it be mentioned?
Discussion
Story 1: As a researcher I want to know the number of publications and the number of authors, both overall and broken down by publication type.
Story 2: As a researcher I want to know the number of publications for each author, both overall and by publication type.
Story 3: As a researcher I want to know the number of publications produced in each year, broken down by publication type.
Story 4: As a researcher I want to know the number of authors who wrote publications in each year, broken down by publication type.

data.text:
•	Verify that the years are displayed in order
•	Verify the number of authors for each type of publication are displayed

Story 3: As a researcher I want to know the number of publications produced in each year, broken down by publication type.

data.text:
•	Verify that the years are displayed in order
•	Verify the number of publications for each type of publication are displayed
• Verify that years with no publications are not displayed

card.name: Story 3: As a researcher I want to know the number of publications produced in each year, broken down by publication type.
Story 2: As a researcher I want to know the number of publications for each author, both overall and by publication type.

data.text:
•	Verify that each of the authors is listed just once
•	Verify that the numbers of publications for each publication type and their total are displayed
•	Adding together the numbers of the publications of the same author, broken down by publication type should sum to the author’s total publications.

card.name: Story 2: As a researcher I want to know the number of publications for each author, both overall and by publication type.
Story 1: As a researcher I want to know the number of publications and the number of authors, both overall and broken down by publication type.

data.text:
•	Verify that the number of publications and the number of authors are displayed to the user for each category of publications as well as their totals
•	Verify that the user cannot make any changes to the shown dataset
•	Adding together the numbers of the publications for each publication type should give the total number of publications

data.text:
Based on the extra reading materials ''Chapter9SampleAccTests.pdf'' which are in blackboard...
Manual testing: “essentially tell us whether the system behaves correctly from the perspective of a user”. NOT about how the system implements that behaviour.

@pauledwards4 @yuegao  I know that Yue generated manualy the results of the small dataset in order to verify that the implemented algorithm is  correct.  That is nice! 
BUT we also need to write manual acceptance tests for each story.

data.text: @pauledwards4  THis is a problem in the Data Quality of the given dataset...  I dont think that we need to get in so much detail.... We may know that "Robert Stevens" & "Robert D. Stevens" is the same person but this is only because we know who Robert Steven is... ! If we didn't know who Rober is, these two names would be two different people...

data.text: Are we planning on automating this?  Only manual tests have been done so far (looking at each view and comparing to manually generated data for small example)

Comments from Robert:
As an aside for the special characters, have you tested it on multiple platforms? the cahracgter encoding is often untrustworthy in many files. The DBLP people may have been very good about it, but I don't know for sure.

As for error handling and missing fields, as a customer I would expect such things to be dealt with. so if the input file is broekn, I'd expect to be told. At this stage |I'd not expect an analysis and a fix, but a stack trace is always unacceptable.

You raise an interesting point about missing data.  It sort of depends on wht's missing. If it's page numbers, then we don't care. If it's year, then it mmay mess things up. by looking at the stories you should work out which data are important and deal with it appropriately - for many it may just be a warning. For publicaitons with mising yeares, you could just lose them, as it messes thing up. again, as a customer, I'd want to know about it and may be make a choice on it's inclusion in the data presented.

data.text: I've added the DTD to the data directory.  If an XML file has any of these it must reference the DTD or it is invalid XML.

card.name: Handle special characters in the author name

data.text:
This is the list from dblp's dtd

    <!ENTITY Agrave  "À" ><!-- capital A, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY Aacute  "Á" ><!-- capital A, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY Acirc   "Â" ><!-- capital A, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY Atilde  "Ã" ><!-- capital A, tilde -->
    <!ENTITY Auml    "Ä" ><!-- capital A, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY Aring   "Å" ><!-- capital A, ring -->
    <!ENTITY AElig   "Æ" ><!-- capital AE diphthong (ligature) -->
    <!ENTITY Ccedil  "Ç" ><!-- capital C, cedilla -->
    <!ENTITY Egrave  "È" ><!-- capital E, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY Eacute  "É" ><!-- capital E, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY Ecirc   "Ê" ><!-- capital E, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY Euml    "Ë" ><!-- capital E, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY Igrave  "Ì" ><!-- capital I, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY Iacute  "Í" ><!-- capital I, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY Icirc   "Î" ><!-- capital I, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY Iuml    "Ï" ><!-- capital I, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY ETH     "Ð" ><!-- capital Eth, Icelandic -->
    <!ENTITY Ntilde  "Ñ" ><!-- capital N, tilde -->
    <!ENTITY Ograve  "Ò" ><!-- capital O, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY Oacute  "Ó" ><!-- capital O, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY Ocirc   "Ô" ><!-- capital O, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY Otilde  "Õ" ><!-- capital O, tilde -->
    <!ENTITY Ouml    "Ö" ><!-- capital O, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY Oslash  "Ø" ><!-- capital O, slash -->
    <!ENTITY Ugrave  "Ù" ><!-- capital U, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY Uacute  "Ú" ><!-- capital U, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY Ucirc   "Û" ><!-- capital U, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY Uuml    "Ü" ><!-- capital U, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY Yacute  "Ý" ><!-- capital Y, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY THORN   "Þ" ><!-- capital THORN, Icelandic -->
    <!ENTITY szlig   "ß" ><!-- small sharp s, German (sz ligature) -->
    <!ENTITY agrave  "à" ><!-- small a, grave accent -->   
    <!ENTITY aacute  "á" ><!-- small a, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY acirc   "â" ><!-- small a, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY atilde  "ã" ><!-- small a, tilde -->
    <!ENTITY auml    "ä" ><!-- small a, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY aring   "å" ><!-- small a, ring -->
    <!ENTITY aelig   "æ" ><!-- small ae diphthong (ligature) -->
    <!ENTITY ccedil  "ç" ><!-- small c, cedilla -->
    <!ENTITY egrave  "è" ><!-- small e, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY eacute  "é" ><!-- small e, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY ecirc   "ê" ><!-- small e, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY euml    "ë" ><!-- small e, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY igrave  "ì" ><!-- small i, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY iacute  "í" ><!-- small i, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY icirc   "î" ><!-- small i, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY iuml    "ï" ><!-- small i, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY eth     "ð" ><!-- small eth, Icelandic -->
    <!ENTITY ntilde  "ñ" ><!-- small n, tilde -->
    <!ENTITY ograve  "ò" ><!-- small o, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY oacute  "ó" ><!-- small o, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY ocirc   "ô" ><!-- small o, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY otilde  "õ" ><!-- small o, tilde -->
    <!ENTITY ouml    "ö" ><!-- small o, dieresis or umlaut mark -->

    <!ENTITY oslash  "ø" ><!-- small o, slash -->
    <!ENTITY ugrave  "ù" ><!-- small u, grave accent -->
    <!ENTITY uacute  "ú" ><!-- small u, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY ucirc   "û" ><!-- small u, circumflex accent -->
    <!ENTITY uuml    "ü" ><!-- small u, dieresis or umlaut mark -->
    <!ENTITY yacute  "ý" ><!-- small y, acute accent -->
    <!ENTITY thorn   "þ" ><!-- small thorn, Icelandic -->
    <!ENTITY yuml    "ÿ" ><!-- small y, dieresis or umlaut mark -->

data.text: @yuegao but I do get the same results for the summary!
